data.body:
> Interestingly the material.opacity value is 1 by default but I can change it between about 0 and 2. Is that intend?

Can you demonstrate this with a live example?
~~The changes of the PR are correct. The loader should not set `material.transparent` to `true` only because an `alphaMap` is present.~~

Thanks for sharing the files!

Um, the problem is that your `DAE` file does something which is not supported by `three.js`. Your model expects that `three.js` should sample the alpha value of a `PNG` texture and use it as the opacity value for the model. The problem is that these textures are interpreted as alpha maps. But alpha maps are grayscale textures in `three.js` (see [docs](https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/materials/MeshBasicMaterial.alphaMap)). 

Your PR does not actually solve the problem since the loader still applies invalid textures to `material.alphaMap`. I don't fully understand why your model sets the same textures twice as diffuse and alpha maps. But I assume this is a valid approach of the Collada spec. You can see this here:

```xml
<phong>
<emission>
	<color sid="emission">0 0 0 1</color>
</emission>
<ambient>
	<color sid="ambient">0 0 0 1</color>
</ambient>
<diffuse>
	<texture texture="young_lightskinned_female_diffuse2-sampler"/>  <- diffuse map
</diffuse>
<specular>
	<color sid="specular">0.062745 0.05098 0.05098 1</color>
</specular>
<shininess>
	<float sid="shininess">256</float>
</shininess>
<transparent opaque="A_ONE">
	<texture texture="young_lightskinned_female_diffuse2-sampler"/>  <- alpha map
</transparent>
<index_of_refraction>
	<float sid="index_of_refraction">1</float>
</index_of_refraction>
</phong>
```

Let's try something out: Since you are working in Blender, please use the [glTF Exporter](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Blender-Exporter) and [GLTFLoader](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/examples/js/loaders/GLTFLoader.js) to load your file. It would be interesting to see how `glTF` handles this issue.

I've approved this PR too early, sry 😅. 

If an alpha map is present, we need to set `material.transparent` to `true` since Collada expects that the opacity is controlled over the map.

Ok, I think I get what you mean, maybe there is an issue with Blender Collada exporter.

I didn't know either how is it in the Collada spec, but when I remove the `<transparent>` tag from the `.dae` file manually it seems solves the issue in the loader. (tick) :)

```
            <!--
            <transparent opaque="A_ONE">
              <texture texture="young_lightskinned_female_diffuse2-sampler"/>
            </transparent>
            -->
```

 but here is a couple of things: 

> If an alpha map is present, we need to set material.transparent to true since Collada expects that the opacity is controlled over the map.

The transparent = true and opacity = 1 makes a "half-opacity" transparent model which is confused me. It makes the transparent = true model to seems non-transparent only If I change the opacity over 1, about 1.5 or 2-ish. Why the material.opacity affect the transparency if the "Collada expects that the opacity is controlled over the map"?

> I don't fully understand why your model sets the same textures twice as diffuse and alpha maps. But I assume this is a valid approach of the Collada spec

I think it's valid because in Collada spec:
> Determining Transparency (Opacity)
> If either < transparent > or < transparency > exists then transparency rendering is activated, the
> renderer needs to turn on alpha blending mode, and the following equations define how to combine the
> two values. Use these equations to get the correct results based on the opaque setting of
> < transparent >, where fb is the frame buffer (that is, the image behind what is being rendered) and mat
> is the material color before the transparency calculation.
> • In A_ONE opaque mode:
> result.r = fb.r * (1.0f - transparent.a * transparency) + mat.r *
> (transparent.a * transparency)
> result.g = fb.g * (1.0f - transparent.a * transparency) + mat.g *
> (transparent.a * transparency)
> result.b = fb.b * (1.0f - transparent.a * transparency) + mat.b *
> (transparent.a * transparency)
> result.a = fb.a * (1.0f - transparent.a * transparency) + mat.a *
> (transparent.a * transparency)
> ...
> ...
> The interaction between < transparent > and < transparency > is as follows:
> • If < transparent > does not exist then it has no effect on the equation’s result, and the opaque
> mode is the default opaque mode. This is equivalent to:
>  transparent = < color > 1.0 1.0 1.0 1.0 < /color >
> • If < transparency > does not exist then it has no effect on the equation’s result. This is equivalent
> to a factor that is 1.0:
>  transparency = < float > 1.0 < float >
> • If both < transparent > and < transparency > exist then both are honored. 

In my understanding if I'm following the equations above and assuming my PNG files has not alpha channel, it should shows up my original texture pic without any changes, even with no opacity. (Please correct me if I'm wrong)

> the problem is that your DAE file does something which is not supported by three.js

That would be nice to investigate how it's defined in Collada spec so that we know about the source of the problem in the Blender export or three.js or not but I think you right, the three.js does not support my DAE files however it's fulfill the Collada spec defined structure above so I think it's something which not implemented or supported properly by three.js. If it is the case, it is a CR or bug but not a PR anymore :)

I will trying out the glTF Exporter and GLTFLoader as you mentioned soon and I'll let you know about the results. Now I just left here this comment, just in case may someone else also running in same issue..

Many thanks

PS: sry about my stupidly as I'm a newbee in webgl area..

With GLTFLoader I've got slightly similar issue. When I load my gltf object I got nothing on the screen because the opacity is 0 by default, this value came from metallicRoughness.baseColorFactor[3] (alpha) however my model is not metallic even it's not transparent. I have to iterate trough on the object and set the opacity = 1 in each children like ColladaObject needed to set transparent to true, or just change the transparency to false (or the opacity to 1) in the loader:
![captureok1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3866135/38463000-93d2d562-3ae7-11e8-97a8-89f230010eef.PNG)

But good news for me, the textures looks like much more impressive with gltf at least, so thanks :)

You should definitely use `glTF` since it has many conceptual advantages compared to `Collada`.

Can you also please check if your `DAE` files loads with [Sketchfab](https://sketchfab.com/)?  Their loaders are usually very robust. It would be interesting to see if they can handle your model.
Closing the PR since the changes are not going the be merged.
